newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli unlinked bonds close lower.
newsitem.headline: Israeli unlinked bonds close lower.

text.p: Israeli unlinked bonds closed lower on Thursday in what traders described as a correction in response to a month of steadily declining yields.
* Unlinked government bonds (Gilon -- issued for four years): -0.15 pct to 171.89
* Bank of Israel short-term Makam bills: -0.01 pct to 162.11
Volume was moderate at 162 million shekels with traders saying CPI-linked bonds had reached an equilibrium.
"CPI-linked bonds have been stable over the last week and trading has been very quiet," said Baruch Glicksberg of Clal Insurance.
Traders said CPI-linked short bonds rose slightly while long bonds remained unchanged.
Activity centred on unlinked bonds, which continued to show declines.
"Unlinked bonds rose too fast during the last month and yields became less attractive. What we saw today was a correction," said Amir Eayal at Epsilon Securities.

Prices for unlinked Makams also continued to fall in response to several weeks of declining yields. "Since the beginning of the week Makam yields have risen from 14.3 percent to 14.73 percent," Glicksberg said.
Dollar-linked bonds closed lower due to a mild decline in short bonds while long bonds remained almost unchanged.
Note: Makams are zero-coupon unlinked certificates with durations of three months to one year. The Bank of Israel issues Makams to absorb liquidity.
